trans-unit.source: Converts task-returning asynchronous methods into methods that use the asynchronous programming model used in previous versions of ASP.NET and that is based on begin and end events.
To handle asynchronous tasks in ASP.NET 4.5, you implement the logic to return a task as a <xref:System.Web.TaskEventHandler> delegate.
This model of asynchronous task-based programming supersedes the model used in previous versions of ASP.NET, which bases all event handling on begin and end events.

After you implement a <xref:System.Web.TaskEventHandler> delegate, you can then pass it to the <xref:System.Web.EventHandlerTaskAsyncHelper.%23ctor%2A> constructor, which wraps the task-returning logic and converts the handler to the model that uses begin and end events.
The <xref:System.Web.EventHandlerTaskAsyncHelper> class enables your <xref:System.Web.TaskEventHandler> object to be compatible with the ASP.NET page framework.

When you call the <xref:System.Web.UI.Page.AddOnPreRenderCompleteAsync%2A> method to process the task for an asynchronous page, you can use the <xref:System.Web.EventHandlerTaskAsyncHelper.BeginEventHandler%2A> and <xref:System.Web.EventHandlerTaskAsyncHelper.EndEventHandler%2A> properties to pass the converted begin and event handlers to the method.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.EventHandlerTaskAsyncHelper"></xref> class.
Represents the <xref href="System.Web.BeginEventHandler"></xref> method for an asynchronous task.
The method that handles the begin event for the asynchronous task.
Represents the <xref href="System.Web.EndEventHandler"></xref> method for an asynchronous task.
The method that handles the end event for the asynchronous task.
